title: Charge-Complementary-Ligands Directed Assembly of a Lithium Dimer into a Three-Dimensional Porous Framework
abstract: Constructing metal−organic frameworks from combinations of the lightest possible elements is a useful strategy to improve gas sorption properties. It is shown here that by doubling up, lithium can form porous frameworks mimicking those made from divalent metal ions. Two structures based on lithium dimers were obtained. CPM-42 with a pillared three-dimensional framework is porous and can adsorb different gases.

Lithium ion, the first and the lightest metallic element, has the potential to generate novel materials and properties when used in the construction of metal–organic frameworks. However, so far this potential remains underexplored. Existing materials design methods developed from heavier and higher-valent elements, while extensible to other elements of the same (and perhaps higher) oxidation states are of limited value to the lithium system. To address the unique structural chemistry of monovalent lithium ion, we previously reported a method based on charge-complementary neutral and mononegative N-donor ligands in an effort to mimic ZIF-like frameworks containing monomeric lithium nodes. In this work, we demonstrate the success of this strategy beyond monomeric lithium nodes to include dimeric [Li
clusters. In addition, we demonstrate the successful transitioning of this strategy away from pure N-donor-based ligand pairs into O-donor and mixed N,O-donor based ligand pairs.
text: Crystalline porous materials (CPMs) have attracted wide research interest because their porous property can be useful for many applications including capture and storage of gas molecules.
To improve the gas sorption efficiency, a number of strategies have been developed so far, including creation of exposed metal coordination sites and more recently pore space partition.
A more general strategy is simply the use of different types of inorganic ions and clusters.

Inorganic building units can affect not only the type of framework topologies but also the strength of host–guest interactions, both of which are closely correlated with gas sorption properties. A particularly interesting family of CPMs is those made with low-atomic-mass main-group elements such as Li, Mg, and Al.
The success of this strategy is evident from the gas sorption properties of metal–organic framework (MOF)-74-Mg which has the highest CO
uptake capacity under ambient conditions (298 K and 1 atm) and is significantly better that other inorganic compositions such as MOF-74-M (M = Co, Ni, and Zn) with the same structure.
Our continuing interest in Li-MOFs is in part sustained by the desire to mimic certain features of MOF-74-Mg such as its low molecular mass. Compared to Mg
, the low +1 oxidation state of lithium poses a unique challenge. While structural design and synthetic strategies for transition metal ions such as Co

can be adapted (in a number of cases) for developing Mg-MOFs, Li-MOFs are truly in a class of their own, in terms of framework compositional features or structural properties. So far, the use of dicarboxylate ligands, which has been proven effective in generating porous structures with transition metals, has met with limited success for synthesizing porous lithium organic frameworks.

One common feature in known Li-carboxylate MOFs is that carboxylate oxygens usually bond to two or more lithium ions, which leads to the aggregation of lithium (e.g., Li–O chain) and formation of relatively dense chains or layers.

For MOFs, the separation of inorganic nodes by longer organic ligands (as compared to single O anion) in all directions can lead to greater porosity, and for this reason, there is a desire for creating Li-MOFs based on discrete lithium coordination nodes. A specific strategy for achieving this is the use of lower-charged linkers based on neutral and −1 nitrogen heterocycles.

In the past several years, we have developed two general framework-composition-based methods for creating Li-MOFs. One makes use of the charge-complementary inorganic nodes (mixed inorganic node with different charges such as Li
), which has led to the successful synthesis of boron imidazolate frameworks (BIFs) with zeolitic structures and the general formula of LiB(im)

The second strategy relies on the charge-complementary ligands (i.e., the mixed ligands with different charges such as neutral and −1 ligands, for example, 4,4′-bipyridine and imidazolate) which has led to a family of lithium imidazolate frameworks (LIFs).

With both methods, one-dimensional (1-D) chain and two-dimensional (2-D) layer aggregations of Li–O, usually found with dicarboxylate ligands, do not occur. On the contrary, the structures obtained from our methods are in fact at the other extreme in the size spectrum of the inorganic building units because in both BIFs and LIFs, a single Li
ion serves as the inorganic node (together with B

in the case of BIFs). As is well known, between a single Li node and polymeric Li–O chains and layers, there is also a rich chemistry of Li clusters. For a number of reasons including high porosity, framework stability, structural diversity, and possibility for open metal sites, it is desirable to have such clusters as the framework building units.

cubane-like cluster) are among the best known clusters formed by lithium. These lithium aryloxide clusters can be used in the construction of the extended frameworks, for example, by cross-linking such clusters with neutral bifunctional ligands such as dioxane.

It is worth noting that in such structures both types of framework components (lithium aryloxide clusters and cross-linking ligands) are neutral. Such neutral–neutral connectivity generally results in frameworks whose stability is lower than those constructed from charged building units, for example, negative carboxylate ligands and positive inorganic clusters.

It is therefore desirable to have a strategy to address the twin goals of the strengthening the cluster-ligand linkages while still being able to take advantage of rich chemistry of lithium-aryloxide-type clusters. One family of ligands that could make it possible to accomplish both goals are those integrating pyridal and phenol functionalities. The simplest ligand in this family is 4-hydroxypyridine (HOPy). Such a difference can be best appreciated if donor atoms of the cross-linking ligands are not considered as part of the cluster. With this view, Li-MOFs made from Li-OPh clusters consist of neutral Li-OPh clusters such as Li
cross-linked with neutral ligands such as dioxane, while Li-MOFs made from Li-OPy consist of anion-free positively charged (Li
tetrahedral clusters cross-linked by −1 anionic ligands (Scheme
). This fundamental difference explains the extraordinarily high thermal stability (>500 °C) of the Li-OPy framework.

Note that -OPh is cluster-forming, but not framework-forming. In comparison, -OPy is both cluster-forming and framework-forming.

Despite our initial success with the negative -OPy ligand, we find it useful to explore the Li-OPy system under the conditions involving competing neutral ligands, because such a study can lay the groundwork for developing stable porous Li-MOFs with open lithium sites. Here we report two new Li-MOFs synthesized in this study. One interesting aspect of this work is that it demonstrates the possibility to integrate some features of aforementioned Li-OPh frameworks (neutral cross-linker) with those of Li-OPy frameworks (anionic cross-linker). The new frameworks reported here are based on [Li
clusters, and they are the first examples of Li-MOFs mimicking the well-known square net as well as pillared layered structures, commonly found with transition metals.

The SADABS program was used for absorption correction. The structure was solved by direct methods followed by successive difference Fourier methods. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Computations were performed using SHELXTL and final full-matrix refinements were against

Powder X-ray diffraction experiments were performed on a PANalytical X’Pert Pro MPD diffractometer, equipped with a linear X’Celerator detector, which was operated at 40 kV and 35 mA (CuKα radiation, λ = 1.5418 Å). The data collection was performed at room temperature in the range from 8° to 40° with a step size of ∼0.008°.

Gas sorption experiments were carried out on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 surface area and pore size analyzer. Prior to the measurement, the crystalline sample of CPM-42 was soaked in acetonitrile for 3 days with the solvent replaced three times a day. Then the filtered sample was further dried in the sample tube by using the “degas” function of the surface area analyzer for 10 h at 80 °C. The H
sorption measurement was performed at 77 K, while the CO
sorption was performed at 273 and 298 K, respectively.

The simplicity in the building scheme of CPM-42 makes it relatively easy for structural extension or introduction of functionality. Pillared layered structures based on transition metals have been extensively studied because of their flexibility;
however, this is the first time such structure type is achieved in Li-MOFs, which exhibit quite different chemistry compared to transition metals.

In summary, two new Li-MOFs are reported here. CPM-41 contains Li

dimers linked into a neutral layer by deprotonated mononegative 4-hydroxypyridine and terminated in the third dimension by the solvent DMF molecule. CPM-42 can be conceptually visualized as pillared CPM-41 with the solvent DMF molecules in CPM-41 being replaced by pillaring ligands to create an extended network in the third dimension. These two Li-MOFs bear significant resemblance to those based on transition-metal paddlewheel units. This work demonstrates the broad applicability of the charge-complementary ligand (CCL) based synthetic strategy first introduced in the synthesis of ZIF-like structures. In contrast with this earlier study with monomeric lithium nodes and N-donor ligand pairs, the work reported here is the first example involving Li

dimeric clusters. The successful transitioning of the CCL strategy away from pure N-donor-based ligand pairs into O-donor and mixed N,O-donor based ligand pairs is also worth noting because it opens up new opportunities in the design of novel Li-MOFs.

Commensurate Adsorption of Hydrocarbons and Alcohols in Microporous Metal Organic Frameworks
Wu, Haohan; Gong, Qihan; Olson, David H.; Li, Jing

A review.  Commensurate adsorption is an interesting and important phenomenon occurring during adsorption processes, where the mol. size and shape of the adsorbate (guest mol.) lead to an orientation and adsorbed amt. (at equil.) that is compatible and self-consistent with the crystal symmetry and pore structure of the adsorbent.  As a new type of adsorbate material with distinctly advantageous features, microporous metal org. frameworks (MMOFs) demonstrate enormous potential for adsorption based applications, including storage, sepn., and purifn. of small gases and hydrocarbons.  Commensurate adsorption of hydrocarbons occurs far more often in MMOFs than in zeolites and related materials, primarily as a result of a vastly greater variety of framework types and richer hierarchy of complexity of the pore structures for the former.  Among numerous structures in which commensurate adsorption has been obsd. in the vicinity of room temp., many have 1D open channels built on pore segments of distinct shape, size, and narrow pore window that closely match with the geometries of hydrocarbon species.
He, Yabing; Zhou, Wei; Qian, Guodong; Chen, Banglin

Natural gas (NG), whose main component is methane, is an attractive fuel for vehicular applications.  Realization of safe, cheap and convenient means and materials for high-capacity methane storage can significantly facilitate the implementation of natural gas fuelled vehicles.  The physisorption based process involving porous materials offers an efficient storage methodol. and the emerging porous metal-org. frameworks have been explored as potential candidates because of their extraordinarily high porosities, tunable pore/cage sizes and easily immobilized functional sites.  In this view, we provide an overview of the current status of metal-org. frameworks for methane storage.
Porous materials with optimal adsorption thermodynamics and kinetics for CO2 separation

Nugent, Patrick; Belmabkhout, Youssef; Burd, Stephen D.; Cairns, Amy J.; Luebke, Ryan; Forrest, Katherine; Pham, Tony; Ma, Shengqian; Space, Brian; Wojtas, Lukasz; Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Zaworotko, Michael J.

Energy costs assocd. with the sepn. and purifn. of industrial commodities (e.g., gases, fine chems., fresh water) currently represent ∼15% of global energy prodn.; the demand for such commodities is projected to triple by 2050 (P. Taylor, 2010).  The challenge of developing effective sepn. and purifn. technologies which have much smaller energy footprints is greater for CO2 than for other gases; in addn. to its involvement in climate change, CO2 is an impurity in natural gas, biogas (biomass-based natural gas), syngas (CO/H2, the main H2 source for refineries), and many other gas streams.  In the context of porous cryst. materials which can exploit equil. and kinetic selectivity, size selectivity and targeted mol. recognition are attractive characteristics for CO2 sepn. and capture, as exemplified by 5A and 13X zeolites (J. Merel, et al., 2008), and metal-org. materials (MOM).  This paper reports that a crystal engineering or reticular chem. strategy which controls pore functionality and pore size in a series of MOM with coordinately satd. metal centers and periodically arrayed hexafluorosilicate anions (SiF52-) enables a kinetics and thermodn. sweet spots offering high volumetric uptake at low CO2 partial pressure (<0.15 bar).  Most importantly, such MOM offer an unprecedented CO2 sorption selectivity over N2, H2, and CH4, even in the presence of moisture.  Thus, these MOM are relevant to CO2 sepn. in the context of post-combustion (flue gas, CO2/N2), pre-combustion (shifted synthesis gas stream, CO2/H2), and natural gas upgrading (natural gas clean-up, CO2/CH4).
Microporous metal-organic framework with potential for carbon dioxide capture at ambient conditions
Xiang Shengchang; He Yabing; Zhang Zhangjing; Wu Hui; Zhou Wei; Krishna Rajamani; Chen Banglin

Carbon dioxide capture and separation are important industrial processes that allow the use of carbon dioxide for the production of a range of chemical products and materials, and to minimize the effects of carbon dioxide emission.  Porous metal-organic frameworks are promising materials to achieve such separations and to replace current technologies, which use aqueous solvents to chemically absorb carbon dioxide.  Here we show that a metal-organic frameworks (UTSA-16) displays high uptake (160 cm(3) cm(-3)) of CO(2) at ambient conditions, making it a potentially useful adsorbent material for post-combustion carbon dioxide capture and biogas stream purification.  This has been further confirmed by simulated breakthrough experiments.  The high storage capacities and selectivities of UTSA-16 for carbon dioxide capture are attributed to the optimal pore cages and the strong binding sites to carbon dioxide, which have been demonstrated by neutron diffraction studies.
Crystalline Inorganic Frameworks with 56-Ring, 64-Ring, and 72-Ring Channels
Lin, Hsin-Yau; Chin, Chih-Yuan; Huang, Hui-Lin; Huang, Wen-Yen; Sie, Ming-Jhe; Huang, Li-Hsun; Lee, Yuan-Han; Lin, Chia-Her; Lii, Kwang-Hwa; Bu, Xianhui; Wang, Sue-Lein
American Association for the Advancement of Science

The development of zeolite-like structures with extra-large pores (>12-membered rings, 12R) has been sporadic and is currently at 30R.  In general, templating via mols. leads to cryst. frameworks, whereas the use of organized assemblies that permit much larger pores produces noncryst. frameworks.  Synthetic methods that generate crystallinity from both discrete templates and organized assemblies represent a viable design strategy for developing cryst. porous inorg. frameworks spanning the micro and meso regimes.  By integrating templating mechanisms for both zeolites and mesoporous silica in a single system, the channel size for gallium zincophosphites can be systematically tuned from 24R and 28R to 40R, 48R, 56R, 64R, and 72R.  Although the materials have low thermal stability and retain their templating aliph. monoamines, single-activator doping of Mn2+ can create white-light photoluminescence.
Dramatic Tuning of Carbon Dioxide Uptake via Metal Substitution in a Coordination Polymer with Cylindrical Pores
Caskey, Stephen R.; Wong-Foy, Antek G.; Matzger, Adam J.
Journal of the American Chemical Society

A series of four isostructural microporous coordination polymers (MCPs) differing in metal compn. is demonstrated to exhibit exceptional uptake of CO2 at low pressures and ambient temp.  These conditions are particularly relevant for capture of flue gas from coal-fired power plants.  A magnesium-based material is presented that is the highest surface area magnesium MCP yet reported and displays ultrahigh affinity based on heat of adsorption for CO2.  This study demonstrates that physisorptive materials can achieve affinities and capacities competitive with amine sorbents while greatly reducing the energy cost assocd. with regeneration.
High H2 adsorption in a microporous metal-organic framework with open metal sites
Chen, Banglin; Ockwig, Nathan W.; Millward, Andrew R.; Contreras, Damacio S.; Yaghi, Omar M.

A copper-based metal-org. framework (MOF) has been synthesized, and its structure has been solved by X-ray crystallog.  The remarkably high hydrogen adsorption properties (2.47 wt%) of this compd. have been studied.
A Metal-Organic Framework with Optimized Open Metal Sites and Pore Spaces for High Methane Storage at Room Temperature
Guo, Zhiyong; Wu, Hui; Srinivas, Gadipelli; Zhou, Yaming; Xiang, Shengchang; Chen, Zhenxia; Yang, Yongtai; Zhou, Wei; O'Keeffe, Michael; Chen, Banglin

A 3D porous metal-org. framework (MOF) complex (UTSA-20) based on a novel trinodal (3,3,4) net of zyg topol. by the self-assembly of the nonlinear hexacarboxylate (BHB) with the paddle-wheel Cu2(COO)4 cluster was prepd.  Although its porosity and surface area are moderate and much lower than those of most highly porous MOFs, the open copper sites and optimal pore spaces within UTSA-20 have enabled the pore spaces to be fully utilized for methane storage, featuring UTSA-20 as the material with the highest methane storage d. (0.222 g·cm-3), and just the third porous MOF whose abs. volumetric methane storage has surpassed the DOE methane storage target of 180 cm3cm-3 at room temp. and 35 bar.  By the immobilization of a high d. of open metal sites and the deliberate control of the pore space for their efficient methane storage, these new porous MOFs are envisioned to be promising media for methane and natural gas storage, particularly for mobile applications.
Pore partition effect on gas sorption properties of an anionic metal-organic framework with exposed Cu2+ coordination sites
Tan, Yan-Xi; He, Yan-Ping; Zhang, Jian

An anionic nanoporous framework [(Me)NH2]3[(Cu4Cl)3(btc)8]·9DMA (1, btc = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate, DMA = N,N-dimethylacetamide) is prepd. with mobile guest cations which can perform ion exchanges with different tetraalkylammonium cations, and the resulting tunable pore structures exhibit interesting pore partition effects on gas storage and sepn.  1 Has exposed Cu2+ coordination sites and can perform ion exchanges with different tetraalkylammonium cations.  This framework material exhibits high and selective CO2 uptake under ambient conditions and cation exchange within this anionic framework creates unusual pore partition effects on either gas adsorption (N2, CO2 or H2) or gas sepn. (CO2/N2).
Pore Space Partition and Charge Separation in Cage-within-Cage Indium-Organic Frameworks with High CO2 Uptake
Zheng, Shou-Tian; Bu, Julia T.; Li, Yu-Fei; Wu, Tao; Zuo, Fan; Feng, Ping-Yun; Bu, Xian-Hui
Journal of the American Chemical Society

The integration of neg. charged single-metal building blocks {In(CO2)4} and pos. charged trimeric clusters {In3O} leads to three unique cage-within-cage-based porous materials, which exhibit not only high hydrothermal, thermal, and photochem. stability but also attractive structural features contributing to a very high CO2 uptake capacity of up to 119.8 L/L at 273 K and 1 atm.  The three porous materials are [(CH3)2NH2][In3O(BTC)2(H2O)3]2[In3(BTC)4]·7DMF·23H2O, [(CH3)2NH2][In3O(BTC)2(H2O)3]2[In(BTC)4/3][In3(BTC)4/3(H2O)]2·solvent and [CH3NH3][In3O(BTC)2(H2O)3]2[In3(BTC)4]·solvent (BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate) and were characterized by x-ray crystallog.
Pore Space Partition by Symmetry-Matching Regulated Ligand Insertion and Dramatic Tuning on Carbon Dioxide Uptake
Zhao, Xiang; Bu, Xianhui; Zhai, Quan-Guo; Tran, Huy; Feng, Pingyun
Journal of the American Chemical Society

Cryst. porous materials (CPMs) with superior CO2 uptake capacity have been prepd. using a ligand insertion pore space partition strategy.  CPM-33b-Ni that contains no open metal sites exhibited the CO2 uptake capacity comparable to MOF-74 with the same metal (Ni) at 298 K and 1 bar.

Two (3,6)-connected porous metal-organic frameworks based on linear trinuclear [Co3(COO)6] and paddlewheel dinuclear [Cu2(COO)4] SBUs: gas adsorption, photocatalytic behaviour, and magnetic properties
Zhao, Jun; Dong, Wen-Wen; Wu, Ya-Pan; Wang, Ye-Nan; Wang, Chao; Li, Dong-Sheng; Zhang, Qi-Chun
Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability

Presented here are two novel (3,6)-connected porous metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) formulated as [Co3(BPT)2(DMF)(bpp)]·DMF [sic [Co3(BPT)2(DMF)2(bpp)]·2DMF] (1) and [(CH3)2NH2][Cu(BPT)]·DMF·2H2O (2) (H3BPT = biphenyl-3,4',5-tricarboxylic acid, bpp = 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane).  Compd. 1 has a 3D neutral framework decorated with one-dimensional hydrophobic channels (diam. 8.778(7) Å) while compd. 2 has an anionic framework contg. one-dimensional hydrophilic channels with a diam. of 8.688(5) Å.  Compd. 1 shows promising visible-light-driven photocatalytic activity for the degrdn. of RhB while compd. 2 exhibits high intake capacities for CO2 (11.90%) and H2 (1.23%), resp.  In addn., temp.-dependent magnetic susceptibility measurements indicated that both 1 and 2 display dominant antiferromagnetic coupling among the adjacent Co(II)/Cu(II) centers.
Generalized Synthesis of Zeolite-Type Metal-Organic Frameworks Encapsulating Immobilized Transition-Metal Clusters
Zheng, Shou-Tian; Mao, Chengyu; Wu, Tao; Lee, Sangyune; Feng, Pingyun; Bu, Xianhui
Journal of the American Chemical Society

Zeolites are generally made from tetrahedral nodes and ditopic linkers.  Reported here is a versatile method based on trifunctional ligands.  Seven zeolite-type MOFs, (Me2NH2)14[{M2(μ-OH)(H2O)6}6{M(H2O)}2In18(BTC)30]·solvent (M = Co (CPM-16-Co), Ni (CPM-16-Ni), Mn (CPM-16-Mn); H3BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid), Ca[{M2(p-murea)6}4In6(BTC)12]·solvent (M = Co (CPM-17-Co), Zn (CPM-17-Zn); p-murea = 1,3-dimethyltetrahydro-2(1H)-pyrimidinone), and (Bu2NH2)7[MIn5(BTC)8]·solvent (M = Co (CPM-26-Co), Zn (CPM-26-Zn)) were prepd. and structurally characterized.  With this method, two functional groups were used to form zeolitic nets, while the third one serves to immobilize metal clusters within the channels.  The process is driven by the coexistence of multiple inorg. building blocks generated in the heterometallic system.  The generality of this method is shown by three distinct metal-org. frameworks mimicking AlPO4-5 (AFI) and BCT zeotypes as well as the cubic lcs topol.  The correlation between the framework topol. and trapped metal species reveals the unique bidirectional control (framework topol. ↔ confined metal species) that may be exploited to create a large family of zeotypes with channels modified by different metal ions and clusters.
Assembly of super-supertetrahedral metal-organic clusters into a hierarchical porous cubic framework
Wang, Le; Morales, Jason; Wu, Tao; Zhao, Xiang; Beyermann, Ward P.; Bu, Xianhui; Feng, Pingyun

A porous framework, [Mn5(TBA)3(HCOO)3(OH)(H2O)2]4·6DMF (denoted CPF-5, CPF = Cryst. Porous Framework; H2TBA = 4-(5-tetrazolyl)benzoic acid), comprising a super-supertetrahedral metal-org. cluster building block was solvothermally prepd.  Its cubic framework represents a multi-level hierarchical architecture and also possesses an interesting magnetic property.
Development of Composite Inorganic Building Blocks for MOFs
Zheng, Shou-Tian; Wu, Tao; Chou, Chengtsung; Fuhr, Addis; Feng, Pingyun; Bu, Xianhui
Journal of the American Chemical Society

A general direction for diversifying metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) is demonstrated by the synthesis of composite inorg. clusters between In and s-, d-, and f-block elements.  Five series of MOFs, CPM-18-M (Me2NH2)[In3M(OH)4(BTC)3(DMF)3] (M = Nd,Sm), CPM-19-M [In3M2O(OH)3(BTB)3(H2O)6]·NO3 (M = Nd, Pr), CPM-20 [InCo2(OH)(INA)3(1,4-BDC)3/2], CPM-21-M [In2M2(OH)2(BTB)8/3(DMA)2] (M = Mn, Co, Cu), and CPM-23 [In2Mg2(OH)2(BTB)8/3(H2O)4], (H3BTC = trimesic acid, H3BTC = 1,3,5-tri(4-carboxyphenyl)benzene, HINA = isonicotinic acid, H2BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid) are prepd. and characterized by crystal structure anal.  These previously unknown indium heterometallic clusters, with various nuclearity, geometry, charge, and metal-to-metal ratios, significantly expand the pool of inorg. building blocks that are highly effective for the construction of porous MOFs with desolvated CPM-19-Nd and CPM-20 demonstrating high H2 and CO2 gas adsorption capacity.

Acta Crystallographica, Section A: Foundations of Crystallography

An account is given of the development of the SHELX system of computer programs from SHELX-76 to the present day.  In addn. to identifying useful innovations that have come into general use through their implementation in SHELX, a crit. anal. is presented of the less-successful features, missed opportunities and desirable improvements for future releases of the software.  An attempt is made to understand how a program originally designed for photog. intensity data, punched cards and computers over 10000 times slower than an av. modern personal computer has managed to survive for so long.  SHELXL is the most widely used program for small-mol. refinement and SHELXS and SHELXD are often employed for structure soln. despite the availability of objectively superior programs.  SHELXL also finds a niche for the refinement of macromols. against high-resoln. or twinned data; SHELXPRO acts as an interface for macromol. applications.  SHELXC, SHELXD and SHELXE are proving useful for the exptl. phasing of macromols., esp. because they are fast and robust and so are often employed in pipelines for high-throughput phasing.  This paper could serve as a general literature citation when one or more of the open-source SHELX programs (and the Bruker AXS version SHELXTL) are employed in the course of a crystal-structure detn.
